body:
# property-no-vendor-prefix

Disallow vendor prefixes for properties.

    a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }
/**         ↑
 * These prefixes */

This rule does not blanketly condemn vendor prefixes. Instead, it uses Autoprefixer’s up-to-date data (from caniuse.com) to know whether a vendor prefix should cause a warning or not. If you’ve included a vendor prefixed property that has a standard alternative, one that Autoprefixer could take care of for you, this rule will warn about it. If, however, you use a non-standard vendor-prefixed property, one that Autoprefixer would ignore and could not provide (such as -webkit-touch-callout),  this rule will ignore it.

The following patterns are considered warnings:

a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }

a { -moz-columns: 2; }

The following patterns are not considered warnings:

a { transform: scale(1); }

a {
columns: 2; }

a { -webkit-touch-callout: none; }
rawBody:
# property-no-vendor-prefix

Disallow vendor prefixes for properties.

```css
    a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }
/**         ↑
 * These prefixes */
```

This rule does not blanketly condemn vendor prefixes.
Instead, it uses [Autoprefixer's](https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer) up-to-date
data (from [caniuse.com](http://caniuse.com/)) to know whether a vendor prefix should
cause a warning or not.
*If you've included a vendor prefixed property that has a standard alternative,
one that Autoprefixer could take care of for you,
this rule will warn about it*.
If, however, you use a non-standard vendor-prefixed property,
one that Autoprefixer would ignore and could not provide (such as `-webkit-touch-callout`), 
this rule will ignore it.

The following patterns are considered warnings:

```css
a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }
```

```css
a { -moz-columns: 2; }
```

The following patterns are *not* considered warnings:

```css
a { transform: scale(1); }
```

```css
a {
columns: 2; }
```

```css
a { -webkit-touch-callout: none; }
```
raw:
---
title: property-no-vendor-prefix
---

# property-no-vendor-prefix

Disallow vendor prefixes for properties.

```css
    a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }
/**         ↑
 * These prefixes */
```

This rule does not blanketly condemn vendor prefixes.
Instead, it uses [Autoprefixer's](https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer) up-to-date
data (from [caniuse.com](http://caniuse.com/)) to know whether a vendor prefix should
cause a warning or not.
*If you've included a vendor prefixed property that has a standard alternative,
one that Autoprefixer could take care of for you,
this rule will warn about it*.
If, however, you use a non-standard vendor-prefixed property,
one that Autoprefixer would ignore and could not provide (such as `-webkit-touch-callout`), 
this rule will ignore it.

The following patterns are considered warnings:

```css
a { -webkit-transform: scale(1); }
```

```css
a { -moz-columns: 2; }
```

The following patterns are *not* considered warnings:

```css
a { transform: scale(1); }
```

```css
a {
columns: 2; }
```

```css
a { -webkit-touch-callout: none; }
```
